description.text:
In the dorms we have industrial carpet on the floors and all commercial doorstops people have or bought slid, were too short or failed. So I turned to Thingiverse and printed every door stop on here and they unfortunately they were destroyed by the door closers or did not work. So I designed a saw like door stop that was taller and did opt have any large openings to get crushed instead it has columns to direct the force to the carpet and grip tighter.  I also incorporated the schools logo in to the door stop. 
My cupcake has been running nonstop to make enough for my floor. the doorstops have been in use for 4 weeks and are all holding up.

description.text:
I've finished printing the bridge, but to view the full picture, you will have to go fullscreen In the old days, all the great abstracters like Picasso had to confine their ideas to their canvasses. In the old days, prototypes of bridges took diligent workers weeks to obtain.
Now, in this presentation for teachers and makers alike, I present...

This little beauty is a creation with elements of design, art, and engineering all incorporated into one mighty model. It can be found online to edit at Abstract 3D Bridge on Tinkercad. Challenge your students or yourself to improve on this basic bridge. Improvements you could make include changing the bridge to become a suspension bridge and creating a realistic, print-in-place shaking bridge!
Also, a great challenge is to tell your students to redesign the bridge as creatively as possible, trying to incorporate as much art as possible.
Combining the free, awesome design of Tinkercad with the power of Makerbot 3D Printers can create truly wonderful things.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Doesn't matter-but go for higher res

Infill:

20%

Notes: The prints should come out nicely.
The above printer brand is what this model is optimized for, but not my printer.

Testing the Bridge After your students print their files, inspect each one minutely. Are there holes where one could fall? Does the bridge provide space underneath for passing vehicles? Is the bridge made with minimal material? How creative are the side designs? Those are just a few of the possible ways to examine the printed item.

Designing Above is the first part of my project-the art. Soon after I designed this, the model evolved into a bridge. As you can see, there are only relatively basic design elements. All you need to clone this is an abstract base, which you can see here, and also a bridge-over, seen below. How to Make Something Like This Feel free to use this as a baseline! Explain how to design it from scratch to students.
For more information, refer to the "Steps" area.

Objectives Students will learn:
-3D Designing
-Engineering
-Art Audience Optimized for...
-Middle Schoolers (Grades 6-8)
-Ages 10-14
-Beginning designers Preparation Students should have...
-Access to a 3D printer in school
-Filament
-A reliable Wi-Fi connection
-Ample computers
Instructors should...
-Have a basic knowledge of Tinkercad
-Be comfortable answering questions
You may want to split the class into groups of two or three. Steps The below text describes how to design and print a bridge similar to this from scratch, but feel free to use this as a baseline.
  • You will want to create the base. Choose your desired base ("Box" works well), place it on the work plane, and scale it.
  • Abstract the base! Add items, create holes, and get creative!
  • Clone the base. Right-click (or control-click), and press either command-C on a Mac or ctrl-C on Windows.
  • Move the clone an appreciable distance away.
  • Create the bridge by using a box or cylinder and expand.
    At this point, this is where you are when you use my bridge as a baseline.
  • From here on, just customize and reiterate your designs.
  • Download the .stl file from Tinkercad (under "Design").
  • Download a slicing program. For this example, I will use Cura (search "Cura download" on the web).
  • Open the slicing program.
  • Configure the print settings (for this Printrbot Simple example, I will use 0.1984 mm layer height, Pronterface UI under "Preferences" and a printing temperature of 208°C).
  • Select the load function and choose your .stl file.
    If you have a tethered printer, read on. If not, you should search the web for instructions.
  • Attach the USB cable to the printer.
  • Select the "Print With USB" function.
  • For ABS, Heat hotend to 250°C and turn heated bed on. For PLA (what I use), heat hotend to 235°C
  • Clear gunk and hit print!
  • Sit back and wait.
  • Let heated bed cool down.
  • Voila! In 18 steps, you have had your students design AND print an abstract art/engineering project!
    • Results Students should now know slightly better 3D design, have a .stl file or finished print, and have gears turning in their head about engineering, art, and 3D printing.

This is an easy access Coax wall box outlet which can accommodate SO239 AND N-type Socket Panel Mount or N-Type Bulkhead Socket made for attaching radio antennas. INTENDED APPLICATION IS SHOWN HERE http://g1ybb.uk/custom-coax-connector-exterior-wall-mount-box/
It has been designed so that it requires NO Support during printing.
It consists of 4 parts in ABS printed using an Ultimaker 2 with default ABS settings 260° C and heated bed at 90°C. The parts were printed without a raft or brim using CubeStick for 2nd Gen printer. The parts were cemented together using PVC Cement which welds the ABS ensuring the parts become one.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

100%

Notes: I used Cube glue stick which worked well to keep part from warping or coming adrift when printing.

Assembly of parts Assembly is done using PVC cement. some part fitting may be required depending on the printer used but shouldnt be more than a rub with a file. the two parts of the wall plate are aligned using some filament (2.85mm) as register pins. The cover rim fits into the recess on the cover. Adjust the lock piece in the lid to suit .
Design of the Coax wall box The wall box was designed in Rhino 3D with the emphasis on easy making without the need for any supports and minimal post processing

description.text: Designed for the Robo3D Plus. Not sure if it fits the older version. Not sure why it wouldn't. I created fans that originally blew air on the tip of the extruder, but the fan was too strong, even a 30mm fan, that it cooled the tip too much and it stopped by prints. This design blows to the sides of the extruder tip and eliminates that issue. The fans I'm using actually came with the Raspberry Pi cases I bought. It does have a couple zip tie hoops to attach wire to. There is a hole above where the fan attaches. This is if you want to add a thumbscrew to make sure your duct doesn't move. I was going to add a place to attach the switch, but I wasn't sure how common the switch was that I have. Added photo of BRIDGE TORTURE TEST (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12925) while using the 30mm fan duct. Bridge Speed :: 2 mm/s
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9pOVA91w9Qp

title: Prusa I3 Bed leveling caliper jig

description.text: Clips around the vertical X smooth rods on the prusa I3 and allows you to use your digital calipers to level the print bed.

This is my first openscad project, It's parametric and I've set the parameters to what works best for me.  I printed this with PLA, and it works pretty well to get the print bed level with respect to the X smooth rods if you don't have a dial gauge.  After that, you need to adjust the (preferably variable) Z endstop to get the proper bed height for printing.  
Edit:  I just created version 2 which has an option to rotate the tool body so the open slot is on the bottom.  This makes it so you can remove the tool without removing the calipers first.  Also, I added a picture that demonstrates its use.

comments.text: So many times when I need something I come here to look and see if a file is already made only to end up designing it myself anyway. Finally for once I found one worth printing! Thank you for this. I also needed to resize the slot but I just dragged it into 123D Design and punched it out a little bigger. 5 minutes from download to print. Awesome :)
comments.author: smskeeter23

comments.text:

First test print was too small but looked really good. Keeping it for if I ever get a caliper with narrower leg.

This is a set to provide a MPCNC IE edition belt tension system for those who do not like the default process.

First of all a big thanks to Allted for his great MPCNC creation.
This is a set to provide a belt tension system for those who do not like the default process, see picture.
I'm providing also a Corner_Block_Lock designed to mount more robust end switches, see picture.
The Corner_Block_Locks are for IE edition only and have additional holes for those who may want to add additional screws for plastic or wood to better distribute pressure. You need to drill carefully the holes in the Corner_Blocks.
I printed my Corner_Block_Locks with 30% infill (I use Kisslicer) for better flexibility.
The biscuits are is to avoid degradation of corner blocks nut box due to pressure. They are used in conjunction with self adhesive felt with the felt side facing up. You may need to adjust the biscuit height as a function of felt height and density. Probably a dense rubber band would be better. 
I'm including also the washers I designed for my machine.
SCAD file for biscuits and washers is included.
Updated  Nov. 28th : MPCNC_Belt_Tensioner_V2.stl updated to better support higher belt tensions

comments.text: Be careful using such large bolts for tension, they really do not need to be very tight.

remixed_from.title: Modified RIT Arm Parts - Solidworks Format

description.text:
These STEP format files are parts that I modified based on the original Enable RIT prosthetic arm. The RIT arm is being phased out of use, and these files are intended for interim use while new designs are being tested and approved. They are intended for those who are already skilled in the fitment and use of the original RIT arm. This design is not endorsed or approved by the Enable organization. This version has a more sleek design that is less bulky and weighs just 303 grams completely assembled and ready for use. It incorporates a whippletree adaptive grip mechanism and a palm utilizing knuckle curvature and thumb relocation to further enhance gripping capabilities. The elastics are separated into knuckle and finger sections for adjustable finger closure rates. Use of these items require careful implementation of sizing methods that may require consultation with a medical professional. By downloading these files, you assume all risk and responsibility for proper fit and use. There is a PDF in the Thing files section listing my print settings and some assembly instructions. These files are available in STL format here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1131463
The native files are available in SolidWorks 2013 format here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1156821

comments.author: DrPlama

comments.text:
No sir,
I can;'t figure out how to we put together a barMountTop with bikeMount. (I used part names). I really enjoyed the phone holder, and resized it for my phone - it's brilliant. But afterall I to mount it on a bike, and there seems to be no connection between phone mount and bike mount. How is it supposed to work?
I tried to rearrange it, but my Sketchup skills are quite limited.
Thanks for quick answer
comments.author: renejsanchez

comments.text: Ah, I think I understand.  The trick is to us 3 screws total.  The first 2 screws should be used to hold  barMountBottom to barMountTop.   These 2 screws are inserted from the barMountBottom side.  The 3rd screw is inserted through bikeMount and into one of the same 2 holes in barMountTop (from the other side).  Of course that means that at least one of the first 2 screws should be short enough to allow room for the 3rd screw.  Ideally, the 3rd screw should be a flat head.

remixed_from.author: masnart39
remixed_from.title: Modified RIT Arm Parts - Solidworks Format

description.text:
These SolidWorks files are parts that I modified based on the original Enable RIT prosthetic arm. The RIT arm is being phased out of use, and these files are intended for interim use while new designs are being tested and approved. They are intended for those who are already skilled in the fitment and use of the original RIT arm. This design is not endorsed or approved by the Enable organization. This version has a more sleek design that is less bulky and weighs just 303 grams completely assembled and ready for use. It incorporates a whippletree adaptive grip mechanism and a palm utilizing knuckle curvature and thumb relocation to further enhance gripping capabilities. The elastics are separated into knuckle and finger sections for adjustable finger closure rates. Use of these items require careful implementation of sizing methods that may require consultation with a medical professional. By downloading these files, you assume all risk and responsibility for proper fit and use. There is a PDF in the Thing files section listing my print settings and some assembly instructions. These files are compatible with SolidWorks version 2013 and newer.
These files are available in STL format here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1131463
These files are available in STEP format here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1156799

title: Table Top/Drone Dual GoPro 360 Camera Rig

description.text:
By Ben Kreimer, BuzzFeed Open Lab Fellow
This is the first prototype of Ben's freestanding, 3D printed 360-degree camera mount for two GoPros and a Zoom H2 or Zoom H2n 360-degree audio recorder. It can also be flown underneath a DJI Phantom 2 quadcopter. An earlier version of this table based configuration was used to film a 360-degree video of the BuzzFeed San Francisco office's Thanksgiving Soylent tasting. 
This 360-degree camera mount is designed to hold two GoPro 3+ Black cameras with the GoPro Dual Hero System and aftermarket 185-degree field-of-view lenses. Conceived as a low cost, low weight, 360-degree camera system for flying on a DJI Phantom 2 drone, it costs a third as much as traditional six GoPro 360-degree camera systems, and has better video quality than consumer 360-degree cameras, along with the ability to stream first-person view video from the front facing GoPro.
The mount comes pre-drilled with two holes matching the DJI Phantom 2 GoPro Mounting Bracket.
Don't forget to print the legs and base!

title: Fume Filter for UP Mini 3D Printer

description.text: A fume filter I designed to fit atop my UP Mini to make the ABS fumes a bit more tolerable. It's designed to fit a 60mm fan, specifically one I salvaged from an old projector: the fan is a Panasonic, model # FBL06A12H, but any old 60mm 12V fan will probably do. Just try to find one with a good static pressure rating or at least high CFM. The filter this is designed for was originially designed to be used in a handheld vacuum. This is the one I bought: http://www.ebay.com/itm/arm-hammer-odor-vacuum-durabrand-hf22-/151842065214?hash=item235a7e0b3e:g:6UYAAOSw14xWFhsS The bottom plate goes in after the fan is in place.

title: Laser engraver rotary tool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A very simple rotary attachment for a laser engraver using standard reprap parts.
This uses two NEMA 17 motor wired in parallel. It is cut from 1/4" MDF. The design is simple intentionally so it can be modified and changed to fit your need. I went with two motors so there is no belts or gears or extra stuff making it more complicated. A little trick is if you resize the rollers on the threaded rod (either the printed or cut one) to match the same size as your gear pulley on your Y-Axis then you won't have to modify your steps to run the engraver. Mine was .85" in diameter. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bCmKmEdohK4 Parts:
2 NEMA 17 motors
2 5mm to 8mm couplers
2 8mm threaded rods about 8 inches long
4 F60ZZ Flanged bearings
(regular 608 bearings will work just fine but you will need a few extra M8 bolts)
12 M8 nuts
1 Wood glue

comments.author: Bill1959Bill

comments.text: The K40 will drive a single Nema17, that is what is using on the X and Y axis. Running two motors on the same driver however will not work. But I use this design with only one driven roller on my K40 and it works great. I plug it into the Y axis stepper connection on my controller (I am running a Ramps setup, not the stock Moshi or Nano board)

NEMA 17 motors are so cheap it's almost the same price.

This is a stereographic projection of a classic Celtic knot, but modified so that there is an integrated heart as opposed to a separate ring. Put the model on a flat table, then put a point light (LED will work well) at exactly 100 mm above the table above the center of the model. You can also print the included cap, which lets you install a 5mm LED in the correct place. I've also included the model and the cap combined, but good luck getting supports out! There are also 2 different versions. I've included the cleaned up exported vectors from the SolidWorks sketch I made for this project. In addition, I made a colored bonus of the alternate one. Feel free to use them with the same license. (CC, Attribution, Non-Commercial) I made this mainly because I wanted to see if I could make a streographic projection model in SolidWorks. My wife really liked http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1080326 but each time I printed it the small concentric grips would break when I press fit the parts together. Also the base is a little small for actually holding anything. She really wanted one for her desk at work as a Geologist. Well when wifie wants, wifie gets! So I started designing... I also got a little carried away and made a lot of extra parts and fun things to try and add on. I may add more parts as I think of them. Enjoy-
Matt

Notes: Most parts won't require any infill as they are mostly 3-4 walls thick. The Base is the only part that may require infill. I didn't use any rafts or support material, and actually I tried to design it so that support wouldn't be needed. I did design some parts to be glued together, just because it is so much easier. The ArmSocketPressFit is designed to have one of the Drill files glued into the end of it. Of all the parts, the ArmFullPivot is the one that might break when press fit. The ones I printed didn't break, but I might beef them up a bit anyway just because the stress will be along a laminated plane and these tend to break easier.
I use SolidEdge ST8, if anyone would like .par or .step files I can post them. I can save files in about any format, just ask.

description.text:
This is a simple servo mount that you can attach to a standard switch plate. Connect the servo to a microcontroller for a quick home automation project. ///////What You Need:
-Micro sized servo (I used cheap SG90 9G micro servos from ebay)
-Mounting hardware for servo and arm (typically comes with the servo when you buy it)
-arduino //////EXAMPLE ARDUINO CODE:
-You will need to have the Servo.h library installed
-Connect servo to Pin 9, GND, and 5V
-Turns the switch ON right after you connect to power
-Turns the switch OFF after 5s, ON after 10s, OFF after 15s, ON after 20s, then loops.
-You can change or add time intervals as needed ////////POSITIONING*
-Servo neutral position is 60 degrees
-Switch ON position is at 100 degrees, and OFF position is at 20 degrees
-May need to change these numbers depending on you servo. *When programming the servo, the arm should move about +-40 degrees from the neutral position to turn the switch ON and OFF. Experiment with these numbers for best results.

comments.text:
Awesome, glad you like my design! As far as operating the servos with an ON/OFF switch it is much easier to do using an arduino or some other microcontroller. Servos operate through PWM so you wouldn't be able to control one with a switch alone. But, setting one up with arduino is not too difficult. I found this instructable that might help you:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Servo-Controlled-by-Pushbuttons/
It uses tact switches to control the servos and the instructions are well detailed. You would need to play around with the part of the code that lists the angle of the servos. I also have an example arduino code in the thing files that you can easily setup. It should guide you in the right direction. Good luck on your project!

After using my new Z-stage ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10478 ) for a while, I found one annoying problem: there is no easy way to adjust the position manually. With the original Cupcake stage, you just pull on the timing belt. Or install a crank on one of the threaded rods. With 10478, the only way is to turn the threaded rod directly, getting oily fingers in the process. This thing is an auxiliary stepper controller, which can be inserted between the printer's motherboard and stepper drivers. It's based on an ATTYNY44 processor and very few additional parts. Of course you can use this device for any other axis as well, including extruder. Or simply use it as a stepper tester - the input can be left open. There are two buttons, 'up' and 'down'. If you leave them alone, the device passes the motherboard signals through. That is, you can print as normal. When you press either of the buttons, the device takes over and controls the stepper directly. This way, you can make adjustments even during a print.
  • 'up' moves the stepper one way, 'down' the other.
  • After holding a button for 2 seconds the speed is doubled.
  • Pushing and holding both buttons for 2 seconds enters setup mode (LED flashes).
    -- Repeatedly pushing 'up' increases speed
    -- Repeatedly pushing 'down' decreases speed
    -- Pushing both buttons saves new speed setting
    • The source code is in zcrank.c - It uses just under 2K of flash memory.

The PCB can accept ATTINY24/44/84 processors, either in DIL (through hole) or SO14 (surface mount) package. P1 is the ISP (programming) header, P2 is the stepper signal output, P3 is the stepper signal input and P4 is for power and external buttons. The P2/P3 pin assignment is the same as the V2.3 stepper motor drivers, among others. 1-2=GND, 3=Step, 4=Dir, 5=/Enable, 6=Min, 7=Max, 8-10=GND. The endstop signals (Min/Max) are passed through, but ignored. See picture for how to connect to a Cupcake. You need to make up an additional stepper cable (ribbon cable with 10-pin IDC header) and insert the device between the motherboard and the stepper driver. You also need to provide +5V to P4/pin1. The 6-pin header on the motherboard can be used for this. The attached zcrank.hex file was compiled for ATTINY44, for other processors you need to recompile. Change the -mmcu option to match: avr-gcc -Os -mmcu=attiny44 -o zcrank.elf zcrank.c
avr-objcopy -j .text -j .data -O ihex zcrank.elf zcrank.hex Please note that the FLASH fuses in the processor must be programmed for 8MHz internal clock (0xe2dfff). I've got a few empty PCBs spare, which I'm willing to send to the first 5 people who want one.

description.text:
For the MakeItLoud comp I have joined 80mm and 70mm together as in main picture.
(70 and 80 in cover photo with caps and connectors) see Post printing assembly instructions.
I'm now very happy with my design/entry, and happy to share with everyone to print & create their own tunes!
See video below of whistle maker tune using 4 joined whistles Design history
My entry for the make it loud comp, I have a good idea but need to establish a good whistle design first before the real design work begins.
Stage two
second design slightly longer, mouth piece opening 1 mm higher (so slightly bigger)
Testing videos added.
Stage three.
Much progress in the last 24 hrs, see the photos below, ideas really started to fire.
Added some new files and you can now see by the pictures where my design is evolving to.
Whistle_evo1 latest design , new mouth piece, added an end cap and connectors.
stage 4
Whistle_evo2 has a pin and hole system to locate and hold whistles parallel when joined together.
connector designed, two required
video test tune of 4 joined whistles (see below)
stage 5
Name change , whistle maker tune
connector clip improvement
stage 6
Whistle_evo3, Flat surface on sides of mouth piece increased to stop curling of assembled whistles
stage 7
Adjusted connector because the design now had to be a tighter fit due to the c shape,and also closer centre dimension.
Stage 8
Decided to keep the joiner as a combination with the connector, seems to work best to hold whistles together.
that completes the design process,

Notes: press print!
You should now download any one or more whistles
Print a cap for each one,
Print connectors or joiners to assemble together as required.
Updated the software to Makerbot desktop and it is a lot faster now very impressed, great to use!

Assembly guide Single whistle consists of whistle body and cap. Cap is tapped into end, it is a tight fit.
Multiple Whistles can be connected with combination of joiners and / or connectors. Both are slid on from the cap end of the whistle. Connectors have an advantage of clipping on. See pictures for positioning, Joiners are quick to print and are a tight fit.
Please keep joiners and connectors away from hole as it will decrease the whistle!
All connectors and joiners are stagged, see pictures.
I found when joining several whistles in a row, extra joiners near the ends were required. side view of assembled connectors, joiner and cap on the end of a whistle tube Top view of connectors and 1 joiner and caps on an 3 whistle tubes. Picture detail In the picture a connector has been added, ready to assemble the next whistle.

whistle maker tune Hi all, did some research on stream train whistles, and thought I would start by modelling up a whistle for some where to start my development for the comp. I need to block the end, as I left it open, I placed the palm of my hand over the opening and blew through the mouth piece,it was very loud! I would consider making the walls thicker to see if it produces a deeper sound.
Sample two up and running have a listen !
Once I got a few sample parts I thought wow, I could make a few at different lengths and design a simple connector to hold them together. Make a mouth piece that could line up to the next whistle, so playing all would be easy. This evolved concept would allow for different colours to be used and by changing the order would create different tunes, now that's pretty cool for everyone. Create your own coloured tune!
added improvements to design,
Increased depth of side of mouth piece to have more bearing surface to help keep assembled whistles straight.
Resigned connector increase height and added angle face to interlock with it self when connecting whistles.
I have stl files from 60mm going by 10mm increments to 120mm though using editing software you can trim or lengthen to suit.
By the way I like the mystery of printing to "a length" and then assembling them randomly to produce a new tune!
Very creative. Cap for end Cap for end finally got a cap to fit tightly on the end , it needs a good tap to fit snuggly on.
I have also increased the wall thickness of the tube, connectors and sound improvement connectors and sound improvement Ok to assemble the whistles I have designed I rectangle piece around the mouth piece,
I noticed a slight air noise with the whistle noise, I placed my fingers either side of the hole and it went away. Then added some tape on the side of the opening, so I will model this in to the design as it stops the air noise!
So some more modelling tonight , Australia time. Ring connetors, first design Ring connectors designed to hold whistles together, so now you can print different lengths and make music, the first connection the first connection Joined up the original whistle and a couple of newer models , I am pleased with my design evolution, Model with pin and hole Model with pin and hole Once the whistles were connected they rotated slightly so I have added a pin and hole locating system to hole them inline for stability. yet to be tested! Testing of black at100mm, Orange at 90mm, Green at 120mm and blue at 60mmm Assembled whistle maker tune to evaluate connectors and sound. Noted required improvements and redesigned. redesigned clip that is used staggered and reversed on it self, see assembly pictures. view of assembled model with new connectors View from above with connectors

Beeing out in the wild with my flashlight and doing the strobist requires always a spare set of full batteries. To keep them together I made these small cups to be placed over the ends of the batteries to keep them together. I figures out that the accuracy of my printer ( Leapfrog creatr ) messes a little bit with the perfect fit of the parts. I would recommend to give it a try first and test the fit. If printed correctly the caps should slide over the batteries a little bit tight and should keep on. I used a small rubber band for the ones that does not fit perfectly.
Available is a size for AA and AAA. Maybe I will try to make a mould out of these and make some rubber ones.

comments.text: I tried to make a mold, and it worked - but my two-part-mold was really hard to fill with oogoo, the sugru rubber substitute you do yourself with bathroom silicone and corn starch. I used http://tinkercad.comtinkercad.com for making the mold, really easy - you just import your .stl and make it a "hole-object" and the make a box for it to be a hole inside. Next I'm trying a 3-part mold, or possibly 4-part - so it just falls away from the cured rubber. I got my first test out - but I can't post a pic here to show the result. Maybe I can post a "made-picture"? Hmm.

My practice of reaction-diffusion model.
The reaction-diffusion system is a model to generate pattern of surface of some animals (such as zebra or fish). Nice explanation here: http://www.karlsims.com/rd.html .
Calculated sphere world with C program, create OpenSCAD sub program (almost C program does everything).

Printer:

Da Vinci 2.0 Duo

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes: To change reaction-diffusion pattern (various parameters of reaction-diffusion, random seed, resolution, # of iteration), edit "rdball2.c", compile and run, redirect output to "rdball-sub.scad". The C program output is OpenSCAD subroutine which draws single polyhedron, so the OpenSCAD main program "rdball.scad" is one-liner. The -inner.stl and -outer.stl file is modified with blender. Draw a sphere with certain radius in the rdball, then cut the rdball i(boolean difference) by the ball for the outer, calculate boolean union with the ball for the inner. I printed out with dual filament 3D printer for for each color.

The algorithm is Gray-Scott model on sphere world.  The sphere is covered by (almost the same size of) triangles, and each crossings (has 6 or 4 neighbors) has the "u" and "v" values of Gray-Scott model.  The Laplacian is calculated on the network (thanks to Dr. Ide, Kanagawa Univ.).  The sphere is, actually simulated by inscribing octahedron, projected onto the sphere surface.
The shown .stl files are, constant k/f/ru/rv program (rdball2.stl) and k varies depending to the z height (latitude) of the ball (rdball2-vary.stl).  Both could be generated by INITK1 and INITK2 value in the C program.
The C program knows coords of each node ("points" of polyhedron() in OpenSCAD), relationship between each node ("faces" of polyhedron()), so create OpenSCAD module by the C program, and that's almost everything. :-)

author: pongo

description.text:
Yet another Voronoi style lamp. I was inspired by Marellov "Voronoi lamp " (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:584714) and wanted to do my own in OpenSCAD. Generates a set of Voronoi regions in 3-space with a small rounded gap between them, then subtract these from a cube and add a frame and adds a space inside for a small LED light source. I added the thin walls to the model to serve as support. Hopefully they can be removed... Done with OpenSCAD so you can tweak the parameters and make your own design. There are still a lot of magic numbers so the code could use some re-factoring. Sorry about that. You can get a different set of points by changing the value of 'seed' on line 46. Then adjust the other parameters so you get a nice looking design without having to wait for the generator. This can takes about 2 1/2 minutes on my PC of the 3 x 3 x 5 array used here. The 3D Voronoi generator is my 3D extension of work done by felipesanches (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:47649) Thanks for looking!
Bob M

print_settings.Printer:: Da Vinci 1.0A hacked with E3D-v6 and Repetier V92

description.text:
Replacement knobs for Rubbermaid branded Tricam Industries 4-foot step ladder: Home Depot model # RM-AUL3, catalog #203124317. Looks like it will also work for the RM-AUL3G/205548469 and other Tricam models but I haven't confirmed.
I dropped a box on the original handle on my ladder and broke it. Love this light little ladder, it's so handy. No other damage so I fixed it with these. I drilled out the original rivets holding the handle and installed these knobs instead. Works great. 
Of course, it's a mod to a weight-supporting ladder so use at your own risk. Obviously if your ladder is damaged enough to break the handle, carefully evaluate it to be sure its safe to continue using. Also, just a heads-up - while the original had a handle across the wide step to keep you from walking off it, these are knobs on each side so there is nothing to remind you not to step off the top step. Use care.
***2015.11.28 7a EST uploaded improved model with more clearance for nut.

Notes: Duplicate and mirror the part in your print settings - you'll need a left and right.

Use 2 #8-32 x 1/2" machine screws with washers and nuts (I used the standard fare available from HD or Lowes.) Drill out the rivets holding the old handle. Remove the old parts. Snap the nuts into the recesses. Slip into the end of the extrusion and bolt together.

The bottom halves of the atomic spheres are not round as they should be (not visible in the photo). Even the top halves are not smooth. There's an unwanted offset before the last few dozen layers.
Note the error in the sphere at the bottom left. The first layers of this sphere were disconnected and displaced. Even the supported model still needs more support for the very 1st layer.

comments.text: If you designed this in OpenSCAD, you can change the resolution using $fn ( https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/OpenSCAD_User_Manual/The_OpenSCAD_Language#sphere ). That should address the issues you're seeing.

title: Tube Cap for Cannondale Lefty Fork

description.text: This is a tub cap that fits on top of a Cannondale lefty fork.  I lost the original that came with the bikes.  I made 2 versions: one has a longer throat portion and it a bit tighter (it also has a circle on the top... something to look at while on the bike for hours).  The other is plain.
I printed these raftlessly.  See some of my other projects for details on the raftless config I've found to work well.

comments.text: Was just about to start designing this when I decided to do a search. Just what I needed!

This is a Viper mk.II starship from the re-imagined series Battlestar Galactica.
Was designed with Miniature Tabletop Gaming in mind.
Robust design without very thin features; designed to be printed as a miniature using a desktop SLA 3D Printer (but I don't see a reason it can't be printed using a FDM printer).
Can be painted and used in games like Wings of War, X-Wing: The Miniature Game, etc. If you print - and especially if you paint it - please upload photos as 'Made'! And if you REALLY like it and would like to encourage me to model more cool things, a donation / Tip would be awesome! =]

Doesn't Matter

title: Flite Test Power Pod Firewall - Repair or Strength

description.text:
This firewall covers the front of your existing FT foamboard power pod to provide strength to the front of your craft OR to repair the front end of a damaged power pod.
There is even holes aligned to attach with a bamboo skewer.
Designed/exported in mm (millimeters).
